children.name: Battle River #3
children.location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
children.Info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1969, and is one section of a three unit station. And has a maximum capacity of 149 megawatts.,

children.name: Battle River #4
children.location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
children.Info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1975, and is one section of a three unit station. And has a maximum capacity of 155 megawatts.

children.name: Battle River #5
children.location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
children.Info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1981, and is one section of a three unit station. And has a maximum capacity of 385 megawatts.

children.name: Genesee #1
children.Info: Genesee power station unit 1 has been in operation since 1994, and is one section of a 2 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts. They also have a comprehensive land reclamation plan in place to return mined land back in to agricultural space.

children.name: Genesee #2
children.Info: Genesee power station unit 2 has been in operation since 1994, and is one section of a 2 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts. They also have a comprehensive land reclamation plan in place to return mined land back in to agricultural space.

children.name: Genesee #3
children.Info: Genesee power station unit 3 has been in operation since 2005, and is one of the most advanced, fuel-efficient, and environmentally-progressive coal-fired facilities in Canada. It has a maximum capacity of 466 megawatts. It is also Canada's first power generation facility to use supercritical combustion technology for greater fuel efficiency and lower emissions.

children.name: H.R. Milner
children.Info: Has been in operation since 1972, and uses a dual fuel steam turbine generator capable of burning both natural gas and coal. It has a maximum capacity of 144 megawatts.

children.name: Keephills #1
children.Info: Keephills #1 has been in operation since 1983 and is one part of a 3 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 395 megawatts

children.name: Keephills #2
children.Info: Keephills #2 has been in operation since 1983 and is one part of a 3 unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 395 megawatts

children.name: Keephills #3
children.Info: Keephills #3 has been in operation since 2011, and is one of Canada’s largest and cleanest coal-fired facilities and one of the most advanced facilities of its kind in the world. And was built to replace the previously existing Wabamun 4 station

children.name: Sheerness #1
children.location: Veterans Memorial Hwy, Sunnynook, AB T0J 3J0
children.Info: It has been in operation since 1986, and is one part of a two unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts, and has received its registration with the International Organization for Standardization’s Model for environmental management systems under ISO 14001.

children.name: Sheerness #2
children.location: Veterans Memorial Hwy, Sunnynook, AB T0J 3J0
children.Info: It has been in operation since 1990, and is one part of a two unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400 megawatts, and has received its registration with the International Organization for Standardization’s Model for environmental management systems under ISO 14001.

children.name: Sundance #3
children.Info: Was built in 1976 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 368 megawatts.

children.name: Sundance #4
children.Info: Was built in 1977 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 406 megawatts.

children.name: Sundance #5
children.Info: Was built in 1978 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 406 megawatts.

children.name: Sundance #3
children.Info: Was built in 1980 and is one unit of a now 5 part station after Sundance 1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 401 megawatts.

children.name: Bighorn Hydro
children.info:
Has been in operation since 1972, and is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes, balancing out shortages due to unexpected outages, or providing power at times of high demand. It has a maximum
      capicity of 120 megawatts.

children.name: Bow River Hydro
children.info:
Was built in 1954, and is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes, balancing out shortages due to unexpected outages, or providing power at times of high demand. It has a maximum
      capicity of 320 megawatts.

children.name: Brazeau Hydro
children.info:
Was built in 1965 and is Transalta's biggest hydro plant. it is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes, balancing out shortages due to unexpected outages, or providing power at times of high demand. It has a maximum
      capacity of 350 megawatts

children.name: CUPC Oldman River
children.info:
Was built is 2003 and was selected by Alberta Environment to develop the project at the existing dam site near Pincher Creek
      . it has a maximum capacity of 32

children.name: Chin Chute
children.info: a small scale irrigation pipe turbine, with a maximum capacity of 15 megawatts.

children.name: Dickson Dam
children.info:
It was built in 1992, the dam was created to control for floods and low winter flows, to improve quality of the river, to create a recreational resource and to provide a reliable, year-round water supply sufficient for future industrial, regional and municipal growth.
      it has a maximum capacity of 15 megawatts.

children.name: Irrican Hydro
children.info: It was built in 1896, and is a small scale run-of-canal hydro plant in southern Alberta on the St. Mary’s Irrigation System.

children.name: Raymond Reservoir
children.info:
A small hydro plant located beside the Raymond Reservoir, it was built in 1994. And has
      a maximum capacity of 21 megawatts.

children.name: Taylor Hydro
children.info:
It was built in 2000, and operates during the six-month irrigation season each year from April to October.
      it has a maximum capcity of 14 megawatts.

children.name: Ardenville Wind
children.info:
It was built in 2010 and is comprised of 23 80m wind turbines.
      It has a maximum capacity of 167 megawatts

children.name: BUL1 Bull Creek
children.info:
It was built in 2015 and is comprised of 17 GE wind turbines, with a
      combined maximum capacity of 29 megawatts.

children.name: BUL2 Bull Creek
children.info:
It was built in 2015 and is comprised of 17 GE wind turbines, with a
      combined maximum capacity of 29 megawatts.

children.name: Blackspring Ridge
children.info:
It was built in 2014 and is comprised of 166 turbines, and is the
      largest investment of renewable energy in western Canada. And a maimum
      capacity of 300 megawatts.

children.name: Blue Trail Wind
children.info:
Blue Trail was built in 2009, and is comprised of 22, 3 megawatt towers. It has a
      total maximum capacity of 167 megawatts.

children.name: Castle River #1
children.info:
Castle River began operating in 1997 with more units being installed between 2000 and 2001. It is comprised of
      60 turbines and seven addition turbnes located nearby. With a total
      maximum capacity of 44 megawatts.

children.name: Castle Rock Wind Farm
children.info:
Began operation in 2012, and is comprised of 33 turbines, with a total maximum capacity of 77
      megawatts.  Castle Rok Wind Farm will allow for over 130,000 tonnes of CO2 to be avoided.

children.name: Cowley Ridge
children.info: Cowley Ridge wind farm was decommissioned in the spring of 2016.

children.name: Enmax Taber
children.info:
The Taber Wind farm has been in operation since 2007,
      it is comprised of 37 Enercon turibines, which is one of the most sofisticated turbine in the world.
      It has a total maximum capacity of 81 megawatts.

children.name: Ghost Pine
children.info:
Ghost Pine Wind farm was built in 2010, it is comprised of 51 turbines, capable
      of generating enough power for 24,300 homes. it has a total maximum capacity of 82 megawatts.

children.name: Halkirk Wind Power Facility
children.info:
Built in 2012, it is comprised of 83 Vestas-Canadian Wind Technology Inc. turbines.
      it has a total maximum capacity of 150 megawatts.

children.name: Kettles Hill
children.info:
Built in 2 phases spread over 2016 and 2017. it contains 35 turbines. with a
      total maximum capacity of 63 megawatts.

children.name: McBride Lake Windfarm
children.info:
Built in 2003, it has 114 Vesta turbines. and creates enough electricity,
      to reduce carbon dioxide emmissions by 164,500 tonnes annually. It has a total
      maximum capacity of 75 megawatts.

children.name: Oldman 2 Wind Farm 1
children.info:
Built in 2004, Ownership transitioned over to IKEA group in 2014,
      as part of their initiative to has a carbon footprint of zero.
      it has a total maximum capacity to 46 megawatts.

children.name: Soderglen Wind
children.info:
Built in 2006, it is compirsed of  47 turbines, each 65 metres tall.
      it has a total maximum capacity of 71 megawatts.

children.name: Summerview 1
children.info:
Built in 2004, it is comprised of 33 67 metre turbines.
      it has a total maximum capacity of 66 megawatts. and an active contract until 2033.

children.name: Summerview 2
children.info:
Built in 2010, it is unit 2 of 2 for the summerview project. Comprised of 22
      turbines, it has a total maximum capacity of 66 megawatts.

children.name: Suncor Chin Chute
children.info:
Built in 2006, and with 20 turbines. The Chin Chute wind farm has the
      capability of generating power of 11,000 homes. and has a total maximum capacity of 30 megawatts.
children.owner: suncor Energy Products, Inc., Enbridge Inc., and Acciona

children.name: Suncor Magrath
children.info:
Built in 2004, with 20 turbines. it is capable of offsetting 70,000
      tonnes of carbon dioxide per year. And has a maximum capacity of 30 megawatts.
children.owner: Suncor Energy Products, Inc., Enbridge Inc., and Acciona

children.name: Wintering Hills
children.info:
Built in 2011, Wintering Hills is comprised of 55 turbines. And has a
      total maximum capacity of 88 megawatts.

children.name: APF Athabasca
children.info:
Was built in 1993 and continued operation until 2012, it had a maximum capacity of 131 megawatts.
      and is a biomass plant.

children.name: Brooks Solar
children.info:
Built in 2017, Brooks 1 will include 50,000 solar panels, and will be western Canada's first
      utility scale solar project. It will have to maximum capacity of 15 megawatts.

children.name: Cancarb Medicine Hat
children.info:
Cancarb is a leader in the development and manufacturing of Thermal Carbon black. The plant has a
      maximum capacity of 42 megawatts.

children.name: DAI1 Daishowa
children.info:
As a branch of Diashowa pulp factory, it is a biomass plant.
      And it has a maximum capacity of 52 megawatts.

children.name: Gold Creek Facility
children.info: Built in 1999, it is a waste heat generation facility, and has a maximum capacity of 5 megawatts.

children.name: Grande Prairie EcoPower
children.info: Built in 2005, it is a biomass plant, and has a maximum capacity of 25 megawatts.

children.name: NRGreen
children.info:
Operating as a heat recovery plant, it works along the alliance pipline, and works in conjunction with 5 other similar plants.
      it has a maximum capacity of 16 megawatts.

children.name: Slave Lake
children.info:
With the use of methane production from the pulp production, the slave lake pulp mill is able to create
      up to 6 megawatts of power.

children.name: Weldwood #1
children.info:
Using wood waste from surrounding lumber mills, the biomass plant will have a maximum capacity of
      50 megawatts.

children.name: Westlock
children.info: Built in 1997, it utilizes used woody biomass material to create a maximum of 46 megawatts.

children.name: Weyerhaeuser
children.info:
Built as a section of the Grande Praire pul mill, it utilizes the waste from the mill, to create power from biomass.
      It has a maximum capacity of 48 megawatts.

children.name: Whitecourt Power
children.info:
Built in 2012, Whitecourt powers biomass plant has earned the federal governments EcoLogo designation.
      It has a maximum capacity of 25 megawatts.

children.name: AB Newsprint
children.info: This facility has a generating capacity of 65 MW.

children.name: AltaGas Bantry
children.info: Bantry uses natural gas fired electrical peaking generators and total maximum capacity of 7MW

children.name: AltaGas Parkland
children.info: Parkland ses natural gas fired electrical peaking generators and total maximum capacity of 10MW

children.name: Bellshill Power Centre
children.info: Built in 2015 with a total capacity of 5.6 MW.

children.name: Carson Creek
children.info: Carson Creek is a 15MW simple cycle gas turbine that operates during peak demand periods.

children.name: Clover Bar Evergy Centre - Unit 1
children.info: One of three highly-efficient natural-gas turbines power up from standstill to full load in 10 minutes to give Capital Power flexibility to respo​nd to sudden changes in supply and demand. All three units produce a combined capacity of 243MW.

children.name: Clover Bar Evergy Centre - Unit 2
children.info: One of three highly-efficient natural-gas turbines power up from standstill to full load in 10 minutes to give Capital Power flexibility to respo​nd to sudden changes in supply and demand. All three units produce a combined capacity of 243MW.

children.name: Clover Bar Evergy Centre - Unit 3
children.info: One of three highly-efficient natural-gas turbines power up from standstill to full load in 10 minutes to give Capital Power flexibility to respo​nd to sudden changes in supply and demand. All three units produce a combined capacity of 243MW.

children.name: Crossfield Energy Centre #1
children.info: Built in 2009, all three centres have a combined total capacity of 120MW.

children.name: Crossfield Energy Centre #2
children.info: Built in 2009, all three centres have a combined total capacity of 120MW.

children.name: Crossfield Energy Centre #3
children.info: Built in 2009, all three centres have a combined total capacity of 120MW.

children.name: Drywood
children.info: Built in 2000 with a total capacity of 6MW.

children.name: High River
children.info: This facaility has a capacity of approximately 500 MW.

children.name: House Mountain Distributed Generation Facility
children.info: A 6 megawatt (MW) natural gas-fired power facility

children.name: Judy Creek
children.info: A 15MW simple cycle gas faciliy that operates during peak hours.

children.name: Lethbridge Burdett
children.info: Built in 2001 with a capacity of 7MW.

children.name: Lethbridge Coaldale
children.info: Built in 2001 with a capacity of 6MW.

children.name: Lethbridge Taber (ME02)
children.info: Built in 2001 with a capacity of 8MW.

children.info: n/a

children.name: NPC2 JL Landry (NPC2)
children.info: n/a

children.name: Northern Prairie Power Project
children.info: A natural gas plant with a capacity of 85MW

children.name: Poplar Hill Generating Plant
children.info: The 45 megawatt Poplar Hill Generating Plant near Grande Prairie provides northwest Alberta with necessary transmission system support and is an important source of additional electric energy for the Alberta grid.

children.name: Rainbow #5
children.info: This 90 megawatt gas-fired cogeneration and peaking facility is adjacent to a gas plant owned and operated by Husky Oil at Rainbow Lake,

children.name: Ralston (NAT1)
children.info: This plant has a maximum capacity of 20 MW.

children.name: Valley View 1
children.info: The two generation plants have a combined total capacity of 90MW.

children.name: Valley View 2
children.info: The two generation plants have a combined total capacity of 90MW.

children.name: West Cadotte (WCD1)
children.info: A total capacity of 4MW
